outcome.outcome_text: Demonstrate understanding of basic oral French messages in a short concrete sentence, a familiar question, statement, request, instruction or accolade. [L] [RP] [S]

indicator.p: Shares information about feelings, needs, and personal data with an English response, a drawing, gestures, or a French word routinely used in class.
Identifies the day, month and date on a calendar in a statement such as Aujourd’hui c’est le mercredi cinq octobre.
Responds to the questions Qu’est-ce que c’est? Qui est-ce? (e.g., with gestures, drawings, known French words, or using English).
Responds to a sentence ending in s’il vous plaît (e.g., with an action, gesture or with a simple oui/non response).
Responds to accolades such as Très bien! Excellent! (e.g., with a gesture, facial expression, or with a word such as Merci!).
Responds to instructions for several classroom routines, such as Écoutez! (stopping the activity) or Répétez! (repeating the word or phrase).
Matches a spoken French word with an action or a gesture.

outcome.outcome_text: Provide personal information through oral expression supported by extensive prompting. [S] [L]

indicator.p: Makes a simple modeled sentence related to the vocabulary of a theme (e.g., C’est un lion. Voici un crayon. J’ai un chien).
Describes people or oneself doing actions using a model (e.g., Elle saute. Il court. Je marche.).
Uses learned politeness phrases for various situations (e.g., S’il vous plaît. Merci! Excusez-moi!).
Gives a short modeled response to questions (e.g., Qu’est-ce que c’est? C’est un chien. Qui est-ce? C’est maman. Quel temps fait-il? Il fait beau.).
Indicates preferences and non-preferences in a simple sentence, based on models (e.g., J’aime… Je déteste…).
Describes weather with memorized global expressions (e.g., Il fait froid. Il fait chaud. Il fait soleil. Il vente. Il pleut. Il neige. C’est nuageux.).
Expresses feelings by using expressions (e.g., Je suis content(e). Je suis triste.).
Participates in an oral language game with a previously learned word or phrase.

outcome.outcome_text: Demonstrate understanding of key words in a simple, concrete sentence supported by an illustration or photo. [R] [RP]

indicator.p: Locates key words and cognates with support (e.g., on a chart, bulletin board, or interactive whiteboard).
Sorts key words on cards according to criteria with support (e.g., animals, school objects, or foods).
Responds to a shared reading experience (e.g., with drawings, physical actions, matching pictures to words, or by saying an English word).

outcome.outcome_text: Produce a simple French sentence from a model. [W]

indicator.p: Writes a simple, concrete sentence by substituting words (e.g., C’est un lion becomes C’est un tigre).
Labels pictures and illustrations with a simple sentence.

outcome.outcome_text: Use listening or viewing strategies in highly structured situations. [L] [V] [RP]

indicator.p: Before listening or viewing: Prepares for the presentation (e.g., pays attention to a signal, looks at the speaker, is quiet and attentive).
Before listening or viewing: Makes connections to own experiences in English (e.g., when shown a picture, photograph or book cover).
Before listening or viewing: Anticipates the content of the listening experience by making predictions in English.
During listening or viewing: Guesses at the meaning of an unknown word or phrase with support.
During listening or viewing:Tolerates ambiguity by focusing on a familiar word.
During listening or viewing: Associates a gesture, action, or facial image with a message.
During listening or viewing: Associates intonation and expression with a message.
During listening or viewing: finds a cognate in a sentence (e.g., animal for animal, or bleu for blue).
During listening or viewing: Draws a representation of a mental image about the message.
During listening or viewing: Tells about a mental image in English.
After listening or viewing: Identifies, with some teacher support, the content of the listening experience (e.g., drawing pictures or using puppets).

After listening or viewing: Identifies, in English with teacher support, the strategies used to interpret the message, such as watching speaker’s face and gestures, using context clues, listening to the speaker’s intonation and expression.

outcome.outcome_text: Use speaking strategies in highly structured situations. [L] [V] [S]

indicator.p: Imitates the teacher’s gestures and expressions.
Finds words in environmental print (e.g., on charts, in books, posters, and pictures posted on classroom walls).
Practises new phrases in a large group setting.
Makes a gesture to accompany a word.
Self-evaluates participation in oral language games with the use of satisfaction indicators (e.g., Pas trop bien. Assez bien. Bien. Très bien. Excellent. or with an icon).

outcome.outcome_text: Use reading strategies for sentences in modeled situations. [L] [V] [R]

indicator.p: Before shared reading: Makes connections to own experiences in English.
Before shared reading: Predicts content in English or by using a familiar French word.
During shared reading: Looks at illustrations as a context clue.
During shared reading: Recognizes key words such as names and familiar expressions.
Follows word to print correspondence as the teacher reads a line from a familiar song or poem.
During shared reading: Examines word walls, labeled objects or illustrated charts to find meaning.
After shared reading: Verifies predictions by saying oui or non.
After shared reading: Discusses in English what the reading experience was about.
After shared reading: Asks questions in English about story elements needing clarification.
After shared reading: Discusses in English a strategy used to understand the story such as focusing on a familiar word.

outcome.outcome_text: Use writing strategies for sentences in modeled learning situations. [W] [S] [R]

indicator.p: Interacts with the teacher as the teacher writes a sentence.
Examines references (e.g., picture dictionaries, word lists, word walls, charts or bulletin boards).
Writes a short text, filling in a repetitive template.
Writes a short repetitive text, following a template (e.g., C’est maman. C’est papa. C’est moi.).
Contributes a page of repetitive text for a class book based on a theme.
Self-evaluates writing using representative icons or phrases (e.g., ☺ ☹ or C’est bien. C’est comme ci, comme ça. Ce n’est pas bien.).

outcome.outcome_text: Demonstrate acquisition of French language concepts, including:S] [R] [RP]numbers 1-20common question beginningscommon articles and their placement pronouns, their use and placementknowledge of key vocabulary words and phrases linked to themes.

indicator.p: Counts to 20.
Names numbers 1-20 in French.
Names the number of objects in a set of up to 20 objects.
Responds to qui, qu’est-ce que, est-ce que questions using learned expressions.
Identifies and uses un/une and le/la orally in front of common nouns.
Identifies and uses pronouns orally before verbs in a sentence (e.g., je, tu, il, elle, on).

Uses key words from the following themes in a simple sentence, such as Je mange une pomme.Calendar and WeatherMy FamilyMy BackpackZoo or Wild AnimalsSeasonal ClothingHealthy Snack FoodRecreational ActivitiesAlternate Transportation

outcome.outcome_text: Identify elements of Francophone, First Nations, and Métis family cultures. [S] [RP]

indicator.p: Represents Francophone cultures by saying a rhyme or singing a song such as a familiar French song commonly sung to children in Francophone families (e.g., Fais dodo, Frère Jacques, Alouette, Sur le pont d’Avignon) or a comptine (e.g., Un et un, deux or J’ai dix petits doigts).

Describes some aspects of Francophone families, such as names of family members (e.g., maman for mère, papa for père, grand-papa for grand-père, grand-maman for grand-mère) as well as aspects of First Nations families (e.g., moshom for grandmother and kokum for grandfather).

Names some Francophone foods or snacks and tells what holiday or meal they are traditionaly associated to (e.g., la tourtière after midnight during the Christmas season, la poutine for a meal or a snack, la brioche for breakfast).

Names food containers common to Francophone cultures (e.g., le panier à provisions (shopping basket), le panier à salade (salad basket), le sac à provisions (shopping bag), as well as containers common to traditional First Nations cultures such as le pare-flèche (parfleche), le panier au saule rouge (red willow basket), le panier à l’écorce de bouleau (birchbark basket).

Examines clothing items common to Francophone cultures (e.g., le béret, une robe haute-couture, un t-shirt baba-cool (France : t-shirt with imprinted images and slogans), la ceinture fléchée (common to both Métis and Francophone cultures)).
Uses knowledge of Francophone cultures to participate in cultural activities, such as games, singing, and rhymes.
Self-evaluates participation in cultural activities through the use of satisfaction indicators (e.g., Pas trop bien. Assez bien. Bien. Très bien. Excellent. or with an icon).
